Type parameters
Commands that deal with values such as read, write, search and measure take a common set of parameters that are called the type parameters. These parameters are used to describe the value.
The --type parameter specifies the type of the value. The following types are available:
byte
integer
ieee754
text
address
instruction
The following sections will describe each one and their specific parameters.
Byte
This is the most basic type of them all. A byte is a sequence of 8-bits. It is printed in hexadecimal notation.
This type does not have type specific parameters.
Integer
An integer number can be represented in various ways. Proctal supports 8, 16, 32 and 64 bit wide integers, either unsigned or using the two's complement representation for negative numbers and in little endian. It's printed with decimal numbers.
The --integer-endianness parameter can be used to set the endianness. At the time, only little is supported.
The --integer-size parameter can be used to set the number of bits. Only 8, 16, 32 and 64 are supported at the moment.
The --integer-sign parameter can be used to set the sign representation. 2scmpl uses two's complement. unsigned disregards signing altogether.
By default an integer is 8-bit, signed using two's complement and in little endian notation.
IEEE754
These numbers are represented as defined by the IEEE 754-1985 standard. It's printed with decimal numbers.
The --ieee754-precision parameter allows you to pick the precision. You may use single, double or extended.
By the default a floating point number uses single precision.
Text
Text is a single character from a character set. It's printed in UTF-8.
The --text-charset parameter defines the charater set to use. At the moment the only value that is supported is ascii.
By default text uses the ASCII encoding.
Address
This represents a memory address in the computer. It's printed in hexadecimal notation.
This type does not have type specific parameters.
Instruction
This represents a CPU instruction. It's printed in assembly.
The --instruction-arch parameter defines the architecture of the instruction. At the moment only x86-64 is supported.
By default the architecture is the same as the tool was compiled in.
